title: Need help!
content:
I found this cool wooden sign and I love the font, but the seller/maker is no longer around to contact to ask about the font. I have exhausted my limited skills on trying to find the font name, so any help would be very much appreciated. Thanks!

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [4b5d3e51d99518aa731802529891a860.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418200610/http:/typophile.com/files/4b5d3e51d99518aa731802529891a860.jpg) | 43.65 KB |
author: SydVicious

comments.content: What makes you think that it’s based on a font?
Nearly all the other signs this artist cut out where recognizable fonts. I think she was printing out letters and then cutting them out.

The t is almost a match for  
 [Pretorian DT](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418200610/http:/www.identifont.com/list?3+Pretorian%20DT+0+N0Y+1+NG4+1+NHV+2+2ZWF+2+55J+2+38S+5+GM+5+2DPU+5+6L9+5+6BI+7+60Z+7+24F+7+4NM+7+68Q+8+D0O+8+D8Q+11+FU4+14+FUD+14+J17+14+67O+14+J1S+17+J1M+17+FVA+17+1PX+17+J31+23+FU0+23+J30+23+FUC+23).  
The link includes some similar Art Nouveau brush swash fonts.  
I'm not certain if there is a digital font match, but you might find the font by checking the Dover/Solotype books.  
Don
